posts.cooked:
Hello everyone! I am developing a team in the public education network in the interior of Brazil.

As a mentor, we are almost finishing the training for electrical and mechanical engineering, but our programming is stalled due to indecision when choosing an initial language for development:

What I know about the tools (I don’t know much because I’m a beginner in programming, sorry if some terms or statements are wrong, subject to corrections) =

• Python: Easy to understand and get started with codes. Officially supported since 2024 by RoboRIO, stable documentation but few resources in the community)

• Java: The nightmare of about % of developers (not for FRC , due to the large amount of tutorials and diverse resources in the community, such as CD , YouTube, Workshops, Websites, etc.), although difficult to understand at first contact for beginners

• C++: I develop for a battlebot team in which I work, but for FRC I don’t see many teams using it (sorry for the ignorance)

• LabVIEW: The best team in our country used it but migrated to Java, for navigation, odometry, kinematics and various tasks The control system’s actions are facilitated (we had a meeting with them about this). Since it is a block-structured language, there are limitations in terms of organization and programmable logic.

I appreciate everyone’s feedback in advance! Thank you for taking the time to help a rookie team!

Use whatever your mentors have the most proficiency in. If there’s none or it’s a tie, use Java, because it has by far the most community examples and support.

LabVIEW is also being phased out and will in fact no longer be legal in 2027.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
The short answer is “whatever language your mentors can best support you in”.

Students rotate through every ~4 years, but mentors often outlast that, sometimes by a LOT.  Once a team has a few years under their belt, they can start planning out more long-term, but a rookie team should really take advantage of whatever areas that have existing support for.

That said, python and java are the only real answers here.  The new control system coming in 2027 is exceptionally unlikely to support labview, and C++ can get complicated rather quickly.  Java has a significant margin ahead of the other options, tons of existing documentation and other resources, and really isn’t too terrible to learn.  Python is even easier to learn, but can certainly be “done wrong” (as all languages can).  Both java and python are taught as entry-level languages across high school/college classes depending on region.
Fine, thanks Sr.

Fletch1373:

and C++ can get complicated rather quickly

C++ robot code rarely gets complicated; it’s perfectly valid practice to avoid pointers entirely and allocate all subsystems and commands on the stack. The actual issue with C++ is that there is significantly less community support and far fewer examples.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked:
I am going to mostly agree with the other people in this thread. You should probably stick to whatever you have the most experience with (I’d guess that’s why it took so long for 1156 to transition from LabVIEW, actually. They just had enough people with enough experience for it to be actually viable).

However, I would really like to bias you towards Java. I found Java in FRC to not be that bad really, even as a beginner. Also, the community support aspect is great. It is by far the most used language and is likely to stay that way:

I really want to emphasize the community support. Something I realized when I first started programming for our team was that Java, C++ and Python already have enough generic learning material out there. If you have a question about the language itself, you will find an answer somewhere. However, if you need help with frc specific things, such as figuring out how to use a specific motor controller, it really pays off to have such a large userbase backing you.

link_counts.title: [FRC Blog] Control System Beta Testing and Usage Reporting

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
I would heavily encourage Java as it is by far and away the most supported by documentation and the community as a whole.

Of course, if you have mentors who only know one language go in that direction, but often it’s worth having the mentor move towards Java….
100% this

Kotlin!

(Seriously, go with whatever someone has experience in. Seems many people also agree.)

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
C++ can get complicated.

(emphasis mine)

You’re right that it doesn’t have to, but if my first point was followed (use what your mentors can support), then you’ll have someone who is used to using pointers for things.

I can definitely see that. I personally had no issues abandoning pointers for robot code projects in some of my offseason tests, but I’m not going to pretend like suddenly ignoring the heap and writing C++ as if it were Java is a particularly easy paradigm for your average >= C++11 programmer.

Also, going to Java from C++ is relatively easy compared to vice versa. I came into FRC as a C++ only programmer and had absolutely no issues getting through with it.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
As our only programming mentor last year (and fortunately a secondary programming mentor this year), I’d never written a single line of Java and sticking with Java was still the right thing.

I struggled with some of the common patterns in Java and the ecosystem tooling, but the FRC /WPI stuff was super-easy and the overwhelming community mindshare meant lots of examples to learn from.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Fletch1373:

whatever language your mentors can best support you in

crueter:

Use whatever your mentors have the most proficiency in. If there’s none or it’s a tie, use Java

This this this this this and only this.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
A great answer for year one.  But if the answer isn’t Java you should try really hard to recruit a mentor with Java experience (or have an existing one learn it).

Otherwise it’s like showing up at your physics classes with an abacus instead of a calculator.  You can maybe make it work, but finding someone who can help is gonna be tough.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
I showed up as a mentor having never written a line of Java, and much more proficient in Python and C++. And, I’m glad we went with Java.

As far as mentor involvement, I’ve found the following details as the most critical for language choice

Being able to use community code and get help

Being able to spot obvious errors easily

Being able to spot really non-obvious errors and track logic flow easily

Unfortunately, java comes ahead on all three fronts. I’d never want to use Python, because issues like “a variable name is misspelled” can result in correct syntax but wrong behavior, and be extremely challenging to find. In Java, this class of errors is obviously wrong by way of a syntax error. Similarly, if you miss a bracket, it’s an actual error, and not code that reads fine and executes wrong. Having those issues go away lets you focus on the big issues, like actually making your robot work as intended. Back when we had to code computer vision on coprocessors using Python, these sneaky issues were major time sinks that kept us from actually making things work.

Beyond that, you’re basically just doing the same thing: Teaching the basic fundamentals of the language, how to write programs, and using the WPILib Framework + vendor libraries. I don’t think the syntax of any available language is so challenging that being familiar with it is a notable advantage or rules it out*

* (excepting functional languages like Rust, which I encourage them to learn but am not about to teach)

tekdemo:

I’d never want to use Python, because issues like “a variable name is misspelled” can result in correct syntax but wrong behavior, and be extremely challenging to find

How is it so hard to find? If I misspell a variable, the ide tells me there’s a syntax error immediately. Why do you ignore the type checker?

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Type checking is a relatively new feature.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
I’m thinking back to cases where an assignment to an existing variable (but having a typo) instead creates a new variable. This is correct syntax, but incorrect logic. Java forces explicit declarations, minimizing this issue since typo’d variable doesn’t exist, and can’t be assigned to at all. This explicitness is annoying, but gives good structure for finding issues.

That said, I haven’t actually used python in an FRC context, or even recently. I imagine the static analysis tools have significantly improved, but there’s some fundamentals of how Python’s syntax works that I don’t know how would be meaningfully patched out.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
It will also show that the wrongly named variable is unused in that case.

Despite being the creator of RobotPy, I worried a lot about Python for FRC for similar reasons (eg typos resulting in runtime errors) before using it in a modern IDE with type checking extensions in the last 6 months or so… it really is a game changer.

Note Java has its own issues with not initializing variables (null pointer exceptions), etc.

Today, I would agree with the Java recommendation.  For 2027 and beyond, I think Python will be much more common of an entry point because we will have a lot of students starting with Blockly (which generates Python code).  It seems unlikely that teams who start with Blockly will jump to Java instead of Python.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: Do you have a source for LabVIEW being phased out in 2027? Haven’t heard of this from anywhere else and cant find anything online
